liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has urged Australians to "donate responsibly". "The best way to assist people in Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories is to donate money to a reputable organisation with an established presence in the area," the department wrote on social media. "We recommend donating through members of the Australian Council for International Development."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: DFAT issues reminder to Australians wanting to donate

children.content: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has urged Australians to "donate responsibly".

"The best way to assist people in Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories is to donate money to a reputable organisation with an established presence in the area," the department wrote on social media.
"We recommend donating through members of the Australian Council for International Development."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Another flight from Tel Aviv carrying Australians has landed in Dubai overnight, according to Foreign Minister Penny Wong. "We are planning an assisted departure flight from Dubai to Perth tonight," she wrote on social media. She added that due to "diminishing demand for dedicated assisted-departure flights", there were no "immediate plans" for more flights from Tel Aviv. "We continue to work with partners to assist the departure of Australians who want to leave Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories," she said. "Commercial flights departing Tel Aviv remain available."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No 'immediate plans' for more flights for Australians from Israel

children.content: Another flight from Tel Aviv carrying Australians has landed in Dubai overnight, according to Foreign Minister Penny Wong.
"We are planning an assisted departure flight from Dubai to Perth tonight," she wrote on social media.
She added that due to "diminishing demand for dedicated assisted-departure flights", there were no "immediate plans" for more flights from Tel Aviv.
"We continue to work with partners to assist the departure of Australians who want to leave Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories," she said.
"Commercial flights departing Tel Aviv remain available."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Lara Stimpson and Charmayne Allison A group of protesters blocked the entrance to the joint Australian-US Defence facility Pine Gap, near Alice Springs in a pro-Palestinian demonstration this morning. A dozen people holding "Free Palestine" signs were chanting prayers and pro-Palestinian statements, centred around a singular protester who had their arm stuck inside a heavy concrete barrel. It's believed nearly 100 staff and contractors at Pine Gap were prevented from entering the site. Protester and Central Arrernte man Declan-Furber Gillick said the group had gathered to take a stand against the Australian government's "appalling, shameful hypocrisy" in supporting "Israeli continued domination and occupation" of Palestinian lands. "I reject the assertion that Hamas or any Palestinian group armed or otherwise instigated this war," he said. "These recent responses by Hamas as an organisation are … the direct response to decades and decades and decades of repression of the Palestinian people." Northern Territory police and emergency services attended the scene, directing the protestors off the road, while firefighters used an angle grinder to break the barrel open. The main protester has since been arrested by police.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pro-Palestinian protesters block entry to Australian-US Defence facility

children.content: Reporting by
Lara Stimpson and
Charmayne Allison
A group of protesters blocked the entrance to the joint Australian-US Defence facility Pine Gap, near Alice Springs in a pro-Palestinian demonstration this morning.

props.alt: A group of people holding Free Palestine signs stand by the side of the road.

children.content: (ABC News: Lara Stimpson)
A dozen people holding "Free Palestine" signs were chanting prayers and pro-Palestinian statements, centred around a singular protester who had their arm stuck inside a heavy concrete barrel.
It's believed nearly 100 staff and contractors at Pine Gap were prevented from entering the site.

Protester and Central Arrernte man Declan-Furber Gillick said the group had gathered to take a stand against the Australian government's "appalling, shameful hypocrisy" in supporting "Israeli continued domination and occupation" of Palestinian lands.
"I reject the assertion that Hamas or any Palestinian group armed or otherwise instigated this war," he said.
"These recent responses by Hamas as an organisation are … the direct response to decades and decades and decades of repression of the Palestinian people."
Northern Territory police and emergency services attended the scene, directing the protestors off the road, while firefighters used an angle grinder to break the barrel open.
The main protester has since been arrested by police.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas recently announced its chairman Richard Goyder had bowed to shareholder pressure and agreed to leave the troubled airline's board next year, joined by two of his fellow directors — Maxine Brenner and chairwoman of the remuneration committee, Jacqueline Hey. They have agreed to leave at Qantas' interim result in February, while Mr Goyder will step down ahead of the 2024 annual general meeting — but in Goyder's case some say that is not soon enough. You can learn more about that here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zmopL2u9Nxw But it seems investors still want more board rejuvenation at Qantas. On Wednesday Ms Brenner faced a 17 per cent protest vote against her re-election at Telstra, after proxy firm Institutional Shareholder Services recommended against her because of her concurrent board role at the airline. But what for Todd Sampson? The Qantas board's in-house marketing and public relations expert may be the next target of big investors. Proxy adviser Ownership Matters has recommended Mr Sampson be forced to exit the company at the national carrier's upcoming annual general meeting. While another adviser to institutional investors, ISS, "notes" ongoing concerns about accountability, as well as Mr Sampson's role on the remuneration committee. It will be interesting to see how investors react when the airline holds its annual general meeting at the Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre on November 3.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Can Qantas directors like Todd Sampson survive the November 3 AGM?

children.content: Qantas recently announced its chairman Richard Goyder had bowed to shareholder pressure and agreed to leave the troubled airline's board next year, joined by two of his fellow directors — Maxine Brenner and chairwoman of the remuneration committee, Jacqueline Hey.
They have agreed to leave at Qantas' interim result in February, while Mr Goyder will step down ahead of the 2024 annual general meeting — but in Goyder's case some say that is not soon enough.
You can learn more about that here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zmopL2u9Nxw

But it seems investors still want more board rejuvenation at Qantas. On Wednesday Ms Brenner faced a 17 per cent protest vote against her re-election at Telstra, after proxy firm Institutional Shareholder Services recommended against her because of her concurrent board role at the airline.
But what for Todd Sampson? The Qantas board's in-house marketing and public relations expert may be the next target of big investors.
Todd Sampson may come under pressure at the AGM
(ABC News)
Proxy adviser Ownership Matters has recommended Mr Sampson be forced to exit the company at the national carrier's upcoming annual general meeting.
While another adviser to institutional investors, ISS, "notes" ongoing concerns about accountability, as well as Mr Sampson's role on the remuneration committee.
It will be interesting to see how investors react when the airline holds its annual general meeting at the Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre on November 3.
